Treatment: Treatment involves surgical removal of the tumor. Radiation therapy is often used post-surgery. Chemotherapy is reserved for advanced or inoperable cases. Symptom management includes treating associated autoimmune disorders.

Treatment focuses on smoking cessation, inhaled bronchodilators to open airways, corticosteroids to reduce inflammation, pulmonary rehabilitation to improve breathing, and oxygen therapy if needed. Preventing infections with vaccines is also important.

Treatment includes disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) to slow disease progression, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to relieve pain, corticosteroids for flare-ups, and physical therapy to maintain joint mobility.

Drugs.Name: Methotrexate
Drugs.Description: DMARD to reduce immune system activity.

Treatment: Treatment aims to control blood pressure and blood sugar, reduce proteinuria with ACE inhibitors or ARBs, manage complications like anemia and bone disease, and prepare for dialysis or kidney transplant in advanced stages.

Drugs.Name: Lisinopril
Drugs.Description: ACE inhibitor to protect kidney function.

Treatment: Treatment requires lifelong insulin therapy through injections or pump. Blood glucose monitoring and dietary management are crucial. Patient education on hypoglycemia recognition and prevention is essential.

Treatment focuses on symptom management with dopaminergic medications to improve movement, physical therapy for balance and strength, and occupational therapy for daily activities. Deep brain stimulation is considered in advanced cases.

Drugs.Name: Levodopa/Carbidopa
Drugs.Description: Increases dopamine levels to reduce symptoms.

Drugs.Name: Pramipexole
Drugs.Description: Dopamine agonist to mimic dopamine effects.

Treatment: Treatment involves psychotherapy such as cognitive behavioral therapy, antidepressant medications to balance neurotransmitters, lifestyle changes including regular exercise, and in severe cases, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). Patient support and follow-up are key.

Treatment includes avoiding triggers, using inhaled corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation, bronchodilators for symptom relief, and monitoring lung function. Patient education on inhaler technique and action plans is vital.

Treatment involves immunosuppressive medications to control immune activity, anti-inflammatory drugs for symptom relief, and regular monitoring of organ function. Patient education about sun protection and infection prevention is important.

Treatment includes dietary modifications such as increased fiber, stress management techniques, medications to relieve specific symptoms (antispasmodics, laxatives, or anti-diarrheals), and probiotics. Patient education and reassurance are essential.

Treatment includes antithyroid medications to reduce hormone production, beta-blockers to control symptoms, radioactive iodine therapy to ablate the thyroid, and surgery in selected cases. Regular monitoring of thyroid function is essential.

Drugs.Name: Methimazole
Drugs.Description: Antithyroid drug to reduce hormone synthesis.

Treatment: Treatment includes antithyroid drugs to reduce hormone production, beta-blockers to manage symptoms like rapid heart rate, and sometimes radioactive iodine therapy or surgery to remove part or all of the thyroid gland. Regular monitoring of thyroid function is essential.

Drugs.Name: Propylthiouracil
Drugs.Description: Antithyroid medication to inhibit hormone synthesis.

Drugs.Name: Propranolol
Drugs.Description: Beta-blocker to control heart rate and tremors.

Treatment: Treatment involves controlling heart rate or rhythm using medications, preventing blood clots with anticoagulants to reduce stroke risk, and in some cases, procedures like electrical cardioversion or ablation. Lifestyle changes and management of underlying conditions are important.

Treatment includes disease-modifying therapies to slow progression, corticosteroids for acute flare-ups, physical therapy to improve mobility, and symptomatic treatments for pain and spasticity. Regular neurological assessments are necessary.

Drugs.Name: Interferon beta
Drugs.Description: Modifies immune response to slow disease progression.

Treatment: Treatment includes iron supplementation orally or intravenously, identifying and addressing the underlying cause of iron loss such as bleeding, and dietary advice to increase iron-rich food intake. Follow-up blood tests monitor response.

Drugs.Name: Ferrous sulfate
Drugs.Description: Oral iron supplement to restore iron levels.

Treatment: Treatment involves lifestyle changes such as salt restriction and fluid management, medications to improve heart function and relieve symptoms (ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics), and in some cases, devices like pacemakers. Regular monitoring and patient education are crucial.

Drugs.Name: Lisinopril
Drugs.Description: ACE inhibitor to reduce heart workload.

Treatment: Treatment includes topical corticosteroids and vitamin D analogs, phototherapy, systemic medications like methotrexate for severe cases, and biologic agents targeting immune pathways. Moisturizers and avoiding triggers help control symptoms.

Drugs.Name: Calcipotriol
Drugs.Description: Topical vitamin D analog to reduce scaling.

Treatment: Treatment involves eradication of Helicobacter pylori if present using antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors to reduce stomach acid, lifestyle modifications such as avoiding NSAIDs and alcohol, and medications to protect the stomach lining.

Drugs.Name: Omeprazole
Drugs.Description: Proton pump inhibitor to reduce acid production.

Drugs.Name: Amoxicillin
Drugs.Description: Antibiotic to treat H. pylori infection.

Treatment: Treatment includes acute pain relief with NSAIDs or triptans, preventive medications for frequent attacks, lifestyle modifications to avoid triggers, and stress management. Patient education on recognizing prodromal symptoms is important.
Treatment focuses on pain management with analgesics and NSAIDs, physical therapy, weight management, and in severe cases, joint replacement surgery. Assistive devices can help improve function.

Treatment includes antiepileptic drugs to control seizures, lifestyle modifications to avoid seizure triggers, and in some cases, surgery or neurostimulation devices. Regular neurological follow-up is essential.

Treatment requires prolonged antibiotic therapy with multiple drugs to prevent resistance. Directly observed therapy (DOT) is recommended to ensure adherence. Monitoring for drug side effects is necessary.

Drugs.Name: Ethambutol
Drugs.Description: Used in combination to prevent resistance.
